pages.text: Sclerocormus is a basal ichthyosaur from the Early Triassic of China. The tail, longer than the body and head combined, served as a strong propulsion organ, while the tiny head, only around 6% of the total length of the body, was toothless and probably functioned in suction feeding.

The really early appearance of this animal in the fossil record (248 million years ago), only around 4 million years after the end Permian mass extinction event, is testament to the quick recovery of life in the earliest Triassic and the incredible evolutionary radiation of the times. $(br)>$(l)Eats:$() Fish$(br)$(l)Breeds with:$() Fish$(br)$(l)Egg Type:$() Live Birth$(br)$(l)Method of Obtaining:$() Bucket
